snippet: Exhausted by nearly a dozen years of war and fearful of tripping into another one, Americans are opposed to a military strike on Syria, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
abstract: New York Times/CBS News poll shows that broad majority of Americans are opposed to military strike on Syria, even though most say they think Syrian forces used chemical weapons against civilians; findings illustrate the depth of challenge facing Pres Obama as he tries to win support for limited strike from deeply reluctant Congress and American public exhausted by nearly a dozen years of war and fearful of tripping into another one.

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER and MEGAN THEE-BRENAN
byline.contributor: Mark Landler reported from Washington, and Megan Thee-Brenan from New York. Marina Stefan and Dalia Sussman contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: Exhausted by nearly a dozen years of war and fearful of tripping into another one, Americans are opposed to a military strike on Syria, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline.main: Survey Reveals Scant Backing for Syria Strike
headline.print_headline: Survey Reveals Scant Backing For Syria Strike
